data.title: Silicon Graphics Strategy: Intel Inside
data.meta_description: The maker of powerful workstations outlines a comeback strategy that includes an IPO for its MIPS chip-design unit, and a new respect for the Intel chip.
data.text:
As promised, Silicon Graphics Inc. on Tuesday unveiled its new strategy to build Intel technology into its workstations and also focus on the technical computing market. The maker of high-powered workstations and interactive computing systems also said it plans an initial public offering for its MIPS Technologies Inc. unit -- and a US$200 million spending cut, including a 10 percent reduction of SGI's workforce.

MIPS owns architecture for high-volume consumer appliances such as videogame machines and handheld computing devices. Silicon Graphics bought MIPS six years ago to design chips for its computers, but the unit became less important to Silicon Graphics operations as the company moved toward Intel.

In addition to going whole hog with Intel, SGI Chairman Rick Belluzzo, who took over the Mountain View-based company in January, said the company would begin focusing on the technical computing market.

"We must aggressively focus on the markets where our unique strengths in visual computing and high-bandwidth systems add value," Belluzzo said at a press conference in New York. "This ruthless focus will streamline the priorities of the organization. We are in execution mode."

Silicon Graphics has already warned that it would post a significant loss in its fiscal third quarter, ending 31 March, as it continued to lose business to its rivals on both the high and low ends. Silicon Graphics stock was down 31 cents at US$15.75 in morning trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

Belluzzo, who worked at Hewlett-Packard for 22 years, said the company will implement a competitive financial model across the company and reduce costs. The company expects to cut about $200 million in operating expenses next year and reduce staff by nearly 10 percent through divestitures, streamlining, and other efforts.

Steven Gomo, SGI's chief financial officer, said the company's plans would reduce the force "by about 1,000 people" from current levels. The company employs about 10,500 worldwide, 7,700 of which are in the United States. Gomo, speaking at the press conference, also said SGI was aiming to reverse a recent trend of rising costs.

The company is also looking at ways to potentially split off its Cosmo unit which develops multimedia and graphics software technologies. A final decision on how that would take place has not been made, Gomo said.
